intro: Carex terniflora, commonly known as the three-flowered sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its triangular stems and grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-brown flowers in dense clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist to wet habitats such as marshes, bogs, and along stream banks. Carex terniflora plays an important ecological role by stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various invertebrates and birds.
